title: How to Make Malasadas

steps.headline: Combine the teaspoon of sugar and yeast into the warm water.
steps.description: Set the bowl aside for it to dissolve.

steps.headline: Grab another bowl and beat/whisk the eggs until they are thick.
Grab a third bowl and put the flour in that one.
steps.description: Add sugar and salt. Mix well. Make a well (create a hole in the center of the flour) and add the yeast mix, eggs, melted butter, cup  of water and cream.

steps.headline: Beat and mix thoroughly so that it forms into a soft dough.
steps.description: Cover the dough and let it rise until it's doubled in size.

steps.headline: Start heating the oil to 375 degrees F. Use a teaspoon and drop big drops into the oil.
steps.description: Fry the drops until golden brown.

steps.headline: Drain the oil onto paper towels or something that can soak up the oil.
Roll the malasadas into the 2 cups of sugar.
steps.description: If it's a small batch, a freezer ziplock bag is perfect, or a large batch can be put into a tin/foil container. It's better if the malasadas are served hot.

text: Combine the teaspoon of sugar and yeast into the warm water. Set the bowl aside for it to dissolve. Grab another bowl and beat/whisk the eggs until they are thick.  Grab a third bowl and put the flour in that one. Add sugar and salt. Mix well. Make a well (create a hole in the center of the flour) and add the yeast mix, eggs, melted butter, cup  of water and cream. Beat and mix thoroughly so that it forms into a soft dough. Cover the dough and let it rise until it's doubled in size. Start heating the oil to 375 degrees F. Use a teaspoon and drop big drops into the oil. Fry the drops until golden brown. Drain the oil onto paper towels or something that can soak up the oil.  Roll the malasadas into the 2 cups of sugar. If it's a small batch, a freezer ziplock bag is perfect, or a large batch can be put into a tin/foil container. It's better if the malasadas are served hot.
